Award.AwardTitle: In-Situ Experiment and Modeling of Electrode Failures in Li Ion Nano-batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to elucidate the mechanisms of electrochemically driven mechanical failures in silicon nanowire electrodes for Lithium ion batteries. In-situ experiments and modeling of nanoscale batteries will be performed to investigate the failures in single nanowire electrodes. The proposed research involves three tightly coupled thrusts: (i) A nanomechanical testing device will be used to quantitatively measure the mechanical properties of lithiated silicon nanowires. (ii) The in-situ electron microscopy imaging will reveal the real-time processes of electrochemical reaction induced deformation, amorphization, and cracking. (iii) Atomistic and finite element modeling will enable the understanding of stress generation, crack initiation and growth on the time and size scales of battery experiments with atomic scale fidelity.

Advanced battery technologies are critically important for applications from portable electronics to electric vehicles. Lithium ion batteries are presently the best performing ones, but they are limited in capacity and reliability. Silicon is being considered as a promising electrode for Lithium ion batteries, due to its highest theoretical charge capacity. However, Silicon electrodes often suffer from mechanical degradation, leading to capacity fading. Currently, there is a lack of understanding of the stress generation and failure mechanisms in lithiated Silicon. This project will show and explain when, where, and how the crack initiates and propagates in lithiated silicon nanowires. Results will provide insights into electrode failures that cannot be offered by traditional battery testing. This research will provide the basis for understanding, controlling, and mitigating materials degradation in high capacity Lithium ion batteries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advanced battery technologies are critically important for applications from portable electronics to electric vehicles. They are also key to the emerging renewable energy landscape. Lithium ion batteries are presently the best performing one, but they are limited in capacity and reliability. Silicon is being considered as a promising electrode for lithium ion batteries, due to its highest theoretical charge capacity. However, silicon electrodes often suffer from mechanical degradation, leading to capacity fading. Currently, there is a lack of understanding of the stress generation and failure mechanisms in lithiated silicon. 

In this NSF project, we have developed a unique in situ nanoscale battery device inside a transmission electron microscope. This nano-battery device enables us to directly visualize the electrochemical and mechanical processes of lithium insertion and extraction processes inside individual nanomaterials with nanoscale resolution and in real time. Using this nano-battery device, we have studied the lithiation/delithiation-induced phase change, deformation and fracture in a number of high-capacity electrode materials such as crystalline Si nanowires and nanoparticles, amorphous Si nanowires and nanoparticles, and germanium and tin nanoparticles. Meanwhile, we have also developed a chemomechanics model to simulate the lithiation/delithiation of individual Si nanowires and nanoparticles. Our model accounts for the large-strain elastic-plastic deformation, two-phase interface, and orientation-dependent interface mobility. The associated simulation results reveal the mechanistic underpinnings of diffusion, reaction, deformation and fracture during lithiation/delithiation of high-capacity electrode materials. Our major findings are summarized as follows.

  • We have discovered the anomalous anisotropic swelling during the first lithiation of crystalline Si nanowires. Our paper (Liu et al., Nano Lett, 11, 3312-3318, 2011) has been cited for 270+ times since its publication in 2011 (according to Google Scholar).
  • We have also discovered the real-time, atomic-scale mechanism of lithiation in crystalline Si at the lithiation reaction front, i.e., crystalline-amorphous interface. The results revealed the mechanistic origin of the anisotropic swelling in lithiated crystalline Si. This work was published in Nature Nanotechnology (Liu et al., 7, 749-756, 2012).
  • We have discovered the unexpected surface cracking and size-dependent fracture during lithiation of Si nanoparticles. Our paper (Liu et al., ACS Nano 6, 1522-1531, 2012) has been cited for 360+ times since its publication in 2012.
  • We have discovered the unexpected two-phase lithiation mechanism in amorphous Si that has been widely thought to occur by a single-phase lithiation mechanism. Such discovery enables a mechanistic explanation of the anomalous growth of patterned amorphous Si electrodes in our experiments. This work was published in Nano Letters in 2013 (13, 709-715) and the paper has been cited for 120+ times.
  • We have developed a 3D chemomechanical model that can successfully simulate the lithiation-induced anisotropic swelling in individual Si nanowires. In the present model, we developed an effective method to simulate the orientation dependent interface mobility. The model provides a general framework to simulate the evolving two-phase system undergoing large elastic-plastic deformation in a full 3D setting. This work was published in the Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids in 2014 (70, 349-361).
